text: Family Member: Whew. Doctor: Number two. It’s a limited treatment meaning you’re only going to get three infusions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And how it works is we take blood out of him at the Red Cross. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They send it to Atlanta to kind of wake it up. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Then, three days later, I get it back. He gets it in our infusion area and then that’s one treatment. And you do that a total of three times with a week in between. So within six weeks, you are finished with the therapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The PSA normally doesn’t change because we don’t expect it to kill the cells right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways.

text: Family Member: Well what is the something? Doctor: Something is an oral medication. It’s a new oral hormonal therapy. Patient: Okay. Patient: Okay, And um, now with that, and I guess we can talk about it when we decide what we’re going to do. Does that involve a placebo? Doctor: Uhm. Patient: If that involves a placebo – Doctor: One of the two trials. The hormone therapy trial does involve a placebo. The other one does not. The radiotherapy trial does not.

In that, um, I’m up at two o’clock in the morning and go to the bathroom and then go to sleep until anywhere from (between six and eight.) text: Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I had to figure out what was gonna on with your lungs. Healthcare Professional: Hi. Doctor: I have a student in here um because I think we gotta work up why your lungs have these areas that don’t seem right. That seems to be your, your thing, every time I see you we’ve got the prostate, oh no we’ve got a lymph node. You know that kind of thing. Um I’m still gonna send you back to the radiation doctor because he may still want to do radiation. You know you’re already on the shot and the next one is in March. But we gotta figure out what’s going on with your lungs. It’s showing some new things in there that may or may not be something that’s cancer. It may not be cancer. I have no idea. Patient: They says it’s nodules or something. Doctor: Exactly. You know nodules are literally white little spots in your lungs. Who knows what that is? It could be a thousand things. Patient: Yeah well I had the flu and it was pneumonia the same time about three years ago. Doctor: Umm. I don’t know if that’s what it is, but guess what. I’m gonna send you to this good doctor. Dr. S____. He’s right in this clinic also and he’s gonna check you out. He’s probably gonna um make some recommendations about what to do for us to figure this out. But I think that’s important too. Now the good part is you’re already getting the shots. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And you know your PSA was coming down just from doing that. That part’s great but I don’t want to miss all the little details. I want to be right on top of this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Any questions?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
